text: Every body continues in its state of rest, or of uniform motion in a straight line, unless it is compelled to change that state by forces impressed upon it.
chapter: Book 1, Axioms or Laws of Motion, Law I

text: The change of motion is proportional to the motive force impressed; and is made in the direction of the right line in which that force is impressed.
chapter: Book 1, Axioms or Laws of Motion, Law II

text: To every action there is always opposed an equal reaction; or, the mutual actions of two bodies upon each other are always equal, and directed to contrary parts.
chapter: Book 1, Axioms or Laws of Motion, Law III

text: I have not yet been able to discover the cause of these properties of gravity from phenomena, and I feign no hypotheses. For whatever is not deduced from the phenomena must be called a hypothesis; and hypotheses, whether metaphysical or physical, have no place in experimental philosophy.
context: On the scientific method and avoiding speculation

text: If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.
Nature is pleased with simplicity. And nature is no dummy.
context: On the elegance of natural laws

text: Truth is ever to be found in simplicity, and not in the multiplicity and confusion of things.
Absolute space, in its own nature, without regard to anything external, remains always similar and immovable.
context: On the nature of space and time

text: To explain all nature is too difficult a task for any one man or even for any one age. 'Tis much better to do a little with certainty, and leave the rest for others that come after you.
context: On the gradual progress of scientific understanding

text: The center of the system of the world is immovable. This is acknowledged by all, while some contend that the earth, others that the sun, is fixed in that center.
chapter: Book 3, The System of the World
